Greetings, and all the love and kindness I can offer, to my dear brother-in-law. I have received your letter addressed to my brother, and I fully understand its contents and recognize your friendly attitude towards me. I am grateful for this and for all the services you have rendered me.
I was very pleased with the suggestion contained in the letter and I am concerned that I may not be able to repay such kindness. Therefore, dear brother-in-law, I would like to offer you what I can, and await your decision so that the matter can be resolved and both parties can benefit, so that in the future nothing will be done without due consideration and to the detriment of either you, my loyal servant, or myself.
My mother will provide me with five hundred or more guilders for the present, and upon her death (God willing) I will receive eight hundred or nine hundred guilders, along with other small items and household goods. I have confided these matters to you in confidence and I am asking you to find out if I need to ask further questions or if I should seek some other way to secure our needs, and also to write me about the father-in-law’s intention regarding his daughter, how many children there are and if he has any objections to my taking up an honest trade to support us.
If any advice is needed in pursuing this further, I will come to you without delay, as this is my opinion, as if I were there with you in person. Otherwise, I am confident that the daughter will not be lost, as we are known to be honest, cheerful and well-liked.

My stepfather was willing to settle with me for five hundred or a thousand gold coins at this time, and after his death (may God grant it be far off) grant me 800 or 900 gold coins along with other small items and household items, etc. That I have informed you, my trusted friends, in secret, I should ask about the matter, whether I might need to give further inquiry or else contemplate to provide for myself, and also write to me herewith, what his father's (the girl's) opinion was, how many children there were and if it would not be against their will for me to carry out some honest trade, in order to have our support as soon as possible. Then if you should need to provide me with advice concerning such matters, I would come over to you without delay, since this is the content of all my thoughts, as if I were personally with you. Otherwise I am of good hope that the daughter will not be lost, since we are honest, merry, and well-mannered (as you know well) among us. Also my stepfather would share his motherly faithfulness with us, and I (as befitting a devout and honest person) will keep my word; hence no lack, since I am concerned that I might possibly suffer a loss of honour from my counterpart. Therefore I am writing this opinion to you personally, so that you may recognize my heart and, hereby earnestly entreating, command me in all trust. My friendly greetings, and whatever I can do with love and kindness beforehand, to my dear brother-in-law.
I have well understood the content of your letter, addressed to my brother, the scribe, and have recognized your friendly attitude towards me.For this reason, dear brother-in-law, I want to offer you my service in this matter.
I was very pleased with the proposal contained therein, as I am concerned that I could not compare to such people in terms of kindness.
Therefore, dear brother, I want to inform you in secret that my mother will provide me with five hundred or more gold coins, and after her death (may God keep her alive for long) she will give me eight hundred or nine hundred gold coins, together with other small things and household items, etc.I have informed you, my trusted friend, of this in secret, to ask you if I need to inquire further about the matter or think of something else to secure it, and also to write to me what the father of the daughter's opinion would be, how many children there are and whether it would not be against their will for me to use some honest profession to have our livelihood more secure.If you need advice on such things, I would come to you without delay, as this is my opinion, as if I were there in person.Otherwise, I am of good hope that the daughter will not go astray, as we are an honest, cheerful and sociable family (as you know well).My mother would also share her motherly loyalty with us and I (as befits a pious, honest man) will behave accordingly; hence no lack, except that I am concerned that they may take away some of my gains out of respect.

My mother-in-law at this time advised me with five hundred or at least four hundred guilders, and after her departure (may God keep her long) she promised to give me 800 or 900 guilders, plus other small items and household goods etc. That I would have told you, my trusted friend, in secret, I ask you to inquire about whether I need to ask further for the matter or if I should think of securing myself in any other way, and I also write to you herewith what the father of the daughter's will is, how many children and if it is not contrary to them, to use some honest trade for our livelihood, as best as possible. Then if you need advice about such matters, I will come over to you without delay, for the content of all of my opinion is as if I were there personally [!]. Otherwise I am of good hope that the daughter will not be lost, since we are honest, cheerful and popular (as you know well) with us. My mother-in-law will also share her motherly faithfulness with us and I (as a faithful, honest husband) will keep it; therefore no lack, as I take care that I might regretfully recover such honors from my opponent. Therefore I am writing this opinion to you personally, so that you, recognizing my heart, earnestly request me to be entrusted in all trustworthiness.
Moreover, my request is that you do not take offense at my answer not corresponding to your letter; for the aforesaid, my father-in-law has not been at home. Therefore I ask to be informed what has kept you from visiting our wedding, where we have waited for you with great desire etc.
Dated 13th August in the year of our Lord 32.
Ludwig Zechender, your good-willed,
To the honored, well-learned master Heinrich Bully, preacher of God's word in Zurich, my dear brother-in-law.
